section.title: Ethics Case Study: Generational Wealth
section.p: Generational wealth refers to the accumulation of capital across generations in a family, especially of long-term assets that can be passed along from parents to children, like land, homes, and other heirlooms. Generational wealth can lead to the accumulation of privilege, as children of wealthier families have more access to education and jobs - for example, children from wealthy families tend to do better on the SAT test.

Generational wealth can be looked at through the lens of time-value of money. If an asset increases in value then its future value will be greater than its present value. For example, a home purchased in 1985 will be worth more (in the sense of future value) than one purchased for the same price today.
In this activity, we'll look at how generational wealth accumulates from home ownership, and discuss the ethical impact of programs that seek to increase home ownership and build generational wealth.
